stem: The nurse finds an unresponsive infant (<1 year old). After verifying the scene is safe and activating the emergency response system, place the BLS steps in the correct order for a single rescuer.

options.text: Perform the head-tilt/chin-lift (neutral position) to open the airway.
Deliver 2 rescue breaths while covering both the nose and mouth.
Repeat the 30:2 cycle for 2 minutes before using an AED (if not already present).
Check for a brachial pulse and breathing for no more than 10 seconds.
Perform 30 chest compressions using the 'two-finger' technique.

rationale.correct: Infant CPR follows the CAB sequence. (1) Brachial pulse is the standard for infants because the neck (carotid) is often too short/chubby for accurate palpation. (2) High-quality compressions (100-120/min). (3) Neutral sniffing position (over-extension can collapse the compliant trachea). (4) Dual seal (nose/mouth) for the small infant face. (5) Consistency.
rationale.incorrect: Using the carotid pulse for an infant is incorrect and less reliable than the brachial artery.
clinicalPearls: For 2-rescuer infant CPR, the compression-to-breath ratio changes to 15:2 and the 'two thumb-encircling hands' technique is preferred.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember '30:2' for 1 rescuer, '15:2' for 2 rescuers. This applies ONLY to infants and children (not adults).

reviewUnits.heading: Pediatric Basic Life Support (PALS)
reviewUnits.body: Nurses focus on respiratory-driven arrest in peds. If the heart rate is <60 with poor perfusion despite oxygenation, begin chest compressions.
